Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Understanding the pre-conditioning effects of solar radiation and precipitation on post-wildfire erosion
Award.AbstractNarration:
Wildfire is increasing across the United States, and the hazards associated with fire do not end once the fire is extinguished. Burned soils are more susceptible to erosion than regular forest soils, therefore the first rains after a wildfire can generate catastrophic erosion. To predict where the most severe erosion will occur, we must understand how different soils erode after they are burned. This research will explore if landscape aridity (a function of precipitation and radiation) can be used as a predictor of post-fire erosion. This study will investigate if arid soil development on local patches of a mountain range will influence soil erosivity and if the preferential erosion of arid soils leads to mountain asymmetry over long time periods. The results could lead to better predictions of post-wildfire erosion. This research will be conducted under the supervision of Dr. Gary Sheridan, a global expert on the study of post-wildfire erosion, at the University of Melbourne in Australia.

This research will use remote sensing imagery and topographic data to calculate the aridity index across a mountain range in Victoria, Australia. Mapping of the aridity index will effectively delineate where arid soils are likely to form. Fieldwork will involve measurements of soil properties in recently burned areas that were mapped as arid soils, which we will compare with samples obtained from non-arid zones. During the field campaign, we will test in-situ soil hydrologic properties by measuring the water infiltration capacity, the soil shear strength, and the total soil depth above bedrock in soil pits. Numerical modeling will be performed to determine how preferential erosion will effect long-term geomorphic hillslope evolution of a frequently burned landscape. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Australian Academy of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In southeastern Australia wildfire occurs regularly, and the eucalyptus forest ecosystems are adapted to occasional fires. However, wildfire frequency differs depending on hill- slope aspect. Equatorial (north)-facing slopes receive higher solar radiation, and consequently are drier than polar (south)-facing slopes. A drier forest ecosystem type, combined with a typical summer pattern of dry northern-winds in the summer season result in a higher frequency of burning on the equitorial-facing slopes compared to polar-facing slopes. Observations of slope angle also differ by aspect. An airborne LiDAR dataset flown over the Sunday Creek watershed in the Kinglake National Park, Victoria shows that the mean slope angle of polar-facing slopes is 5 degrees steeper than the equatorial- facing slopes. This difference in slope angle results in a hillslope asymmetry that is distinctive in the uplands of southeastern Australia. We have sought to test the hypothesis that the higher frequency of wildfire erosion on equatorial-facing versus polar-facing hill- slopes is the primary driver for the observed hillslope asymmetry.

In order to test this hypothesis we used a simple 2D model that simulates hillslope evolution over 20,000 years. In our model we used a fire frequency of once every 10 years on equatorial-facing slopes, and once in 100 years on polar-facing slopes. Depending on the forest state (burnt or unburnt) and the aspect, we modeled erosion as either nonlinear diffusion or transport-limited fluvial erosion. We limit our model to low-drainage area hillslopes where debris-flows are unlikely to occur. On forested slopes of southeastern Australia overland flow erosion is negligible under normal forest conditions due to the high density of litter and duff on the forest floor and the normally high soil infiltration rates. Therefore, during these periods, erosion only occurs as a result of processes such as hillslope creep and bioturbation. By contrast, after wildfires the lack of obstacles on the forest floor and low infiltration capacity induced by post-fire hydrophobicity result in overland flow erosion on equitorial-facing slopes. Polar-facing slopes do not show overland flow erosion even after wildfire, but we expect that the diffusion processes of hillslope erosion increase in the burnt state. The time of recovery back to pre-wildfire erosional processes differ based on aspect. Polar-facing slopes retain more moisture and therefore forest vegetation can recolonize faster, returning a hillslope to diffusional erosion within 2 years after a fire. Equitorial-facing slopes take 5 years or more to return to pre-fire diffusional erosion conditions. Finally, in addition to erosional processes we simulate use an exponential soil production equation to simulate new soil formation.

Our preliminary results suggest that changes in erosional magnitude associated with the different frequency of wildfire occurrence are sufficient to produce hillslope asymmetry over millennial timescales. This result suggests that in tectonically quiesent, non-glaciated terrain wildfire may be a major driver of longterm hillslope evolution.
